values: & THEIR WORDS LIKE SILENT RAINDROPS FELL [& echoed in the well] There's a term audio producers use when recording. It's called the signal-to-noise ratio, and it's basically referring to the fact that the greater the number of sounds are being recorded, the less any of them has any impact, the more of a jumble it all becomes. That's why when you see microphones outside, they're covered with foam clown noses or the scrotums of particularly shaggy muppets. Cut out the extraneous noises of street and breeze. I mention this because sometimes when I visit you, Internet, I get the sensation that you are a giant stadium, filled to capacity, and every single attendee was told that they would be giving the keynote address. At one o'clock. And now it's 1:03. & I will endeavor to keep this brief, so as not to add overmuch to the commotion. When I was younger I imagined (a flight of fancy that might have become a story, or might still) the construction of a library, assiduously and deliberately assembled, of all the books that were never read. How big would it need to be? The size of the NY Metropolitan Library? The Louvre? The Pentagon? Belgium? How many plaintive, unattended words committed with urgency and sincerity and lost without a trace, except in this strange library. I still wonder about it. How much more so are you, Internet? Within your vast & ever-expanding confines, what enormities of text are floating in neglected servers or languishing in the dreaded oubliettes of tl;dr? All of the forgotten blogs, unseen tweets, articles posted into the yawning thunder of your capacity digital stadium. If the Internet were physical, the Earth would not have enough dust to bury these undistinguished volumes of prose. & thus, LiveJournal, the Sargasso Sea of social media. Only MySpace and Geocities are more hollowed out (unless you are a young Russian, in which case this joint is quite vibrant), their constituents drawn to the brightness & brevity of more colorful sites, where, to quote Arthur Jensen, "All necessities provided, all anxieties tranquilized, all boredoms amused." I miss the thoughtful, sometimes heartfelt, sometimes poignant, sometimes whimsical voices I would encounter here, and the time when such expressions seemed appropriate, instead of memes and soundbites. But I always was a whore for the written word. Most of the friends I had, are no longer here. Some of those that remain here, are no longer friends. But a couple of sweethearts & I have conspired here to make our way here, the way we once did. We will be living fossils, like coelacanths, cruising in the inky, abyssal Madagascarene trenches of the internet, unknown save for perhaps an unsuspecting and very surprised fisherman. And given the reception my writing has gotten over the years, it's only fitting that I should be here, in this graveyard of voices that never made a sound.

OFF MY CHEST [wherein your humble narrator reveals his crankdom] I was in my car listening to the radio when the news of Osama bin-Laden's killing came on. I was on my way to a downtown bar, and while I was there I heard both of the dominant political positions expressed, each driven to their strident, alcohol-soaked extremes. All I could think about it was, that's going to alter the game a bit. What I am unable to understand is the veritable ORGY OF EVIDENCE that has poured forth from the government & the news media regarding this operation. Details which would normally deflected and doused in secrecy are instead paraded forth, with just enough withheld to arouse the casually curious in idle speculation. It's been more than a week, and STILL more details are forthcoming. I know most of my Dear Readers are too young to remember the 1979 effort to rescue the hostages in Iran (under the title Operation Eagle Thrust or some such bombast), but it took dedicated reporters an awful long time to piece together that A) there was an operation, and B)it somehow managed to fuck itself in the ear. Now, maybe my trust in the public dissemination of information has been irreparably tarnished by the fact that said providers of information regularly spin the truth so hard that it staggers around afterwards & ends up puking on its shoes. Maybe I've heard too many lies issued regarding paramilitary operations that were later revealed in all their venomous, squirming glory. But this deluge of normally confidential data sounds like a new method for fashioning a cover-up. Don't get me wrong. Osama is dead. We dumped him in the sea. Some Navy SEAL probably shot him in the eye. What I'm saying ~ and what I can't believe no one else has even postulated ~ is that he was dead when we got there. Occam's razor alone points glaringly to this. You have a man who has chronic kidney disease (to the point where he needs dialysis on a regular basis) who has been living as a fugitive for nearly a decade. You have an American state department desperately trying to create a back-channel line of reliable intel with a reluctant Pakistan, with almost no success, for nearly as long. You have an American military who is chronically unable (not allowed?) to find Osama. You have a Pakistani intelligence community unable (unwilling?) to locate him, & fully aware of the support he garners in certain sectors of the country. What changed? Under what circumstances would it no longer matter if the Pakistanis "discovered" Osama's whereabouts & made that information available for the Americans to discover? If he was already dead. There. I've said it. I would like to believe the story that is being enthusiastically and comprehensively shovelled into my craw. In the long run ~ legalistically, operationally, geopolitically ~ it doesn't make any difference. But I can't shake this feeling.

& SO WE CANNOT REALLY KNOW OURSELVES OR WHAT WE'D REALLY DO [with all your power, with all your power, with all your power, what would you do?] In his masterwork of crackpot science Chariots of the Gods?, Erich von Daniken made the (largely absurd) case for the visitation of extraterrestrial civilizations to the Earth in the distant past. These vastly advanced creatures supposedly are responsible for most of the (remarkably primitive) engineering wonders of the ancient world, perhaps going so far as to genetically alter the human genome to a form that was more to their liking, and then departing without leaving so much as a concrete shelter or piece of non-corroding technology behind. According to the author, humans who witnessed these events cowered in terror, watched with wonder, and incorporated what they saw into their mythologies and art styles for millennia. To support the theory, Daniken points to parallels between accounts and depictions by the ancients of the gods & their deeds, and photos of men in space suits, accounts of nuclear detonations, the mundane wonders of radio, air travel, tv. He points to the remote tribesmen of New Guinea, once visited by US and British soldiers during the Second World War as they built their airstrips to battle the Japanese, and how the tribesmen created a cult around these GI's after their departure, watching the skies, building replicas of airplanes & runways in the hope of enticing back these powerful, exotic visitors. The argument is poppycock. Still, the author stumbles over a profound, unsettling truth. Our civilization does ascend to the stars in fiery chariots. We do communicate any idea, instruction, or image over vast distances instantaneously. We do have access to flying machines, and weapons capable of terrible annihilation. We do rershape the entire earth after our desires, paving it and extracting from it what we will. We do all these things routinely, easily, even thoughtlessly. WE are the gods the ancients were waiting for. We are the result and culmination of millennia of dreams for godlike powers. If any ancient were to be shown even the basics of American life, they would understand us as keepers of divine might. We are what nine hundred generations of people fantasized about, prayed to for deliverance, worshipped, feared. And like those gods they believed in, we are almost blind to the capability in our grasp, caught up in endless cycles of squabbling, nesting, scheming, pettiness, distraction. We would seem, to them, to be just as capricious, mean and indifferent as the dieties they were familiar with. Though our technology is godlike, our behavior is much more like the lemurs we descended from, than the angels our powers demand of us. If you are looking for the divine presence in the heavenly chariot, you need only glance in the next lane over on the freeway, trapped in bumper to bumper, chattering about his business into his bluetooth.

A REMINDER: GO EASY ON 'EM It's the most difficult when you feel blue, to keep a light touch. Sooner or later there comes that time when you feel neglected or isolated or abandoned, and you do the best for yourself but the cheap shots just keep rolling in. And you're sensitized to it, almost looking for it, turning your chin into the expectation of a blow. Because it might mean a chance to fight back, to let the inner animal out of its cage, the joyous rage that comes with tearing something down. But you have to go easy. You're aware of more than you know, and you know more than you think. And all the good you do with that, you could do so much more damage. And unlike good, damage is something no one ever forgets. It stalks off on hard, mean boots, and you can't call it back. You can't change your mind and unhurt someone. Remember that people are fragile, and even when they're handled well they still break so easily. We all get broken sooner or later, sobbing on a curb or staring at nothing with faces lonely as graves. Life teaches its lessons with the subtlety of a tire iron. You don't need to help it along. There is much less evil in the world than you wish there was. There are mostly cross-purposes, and mistakes, and misguided intentions. The failure to forgive. And complicating most of these is pride, the high, wobbling pride of a child on his first bike, in love with potency, heedless of consequence. Ask yourself ~ how much evil have you really done? Well, do you want to add to it now? So go gentle. Do what you have to, but lay it down carefully, like putting a drunk girl to bed, tucked in soft with a glass of water on the nightstand, a chaste kiss goodnight. Do it for yourself, because you know hatred is a smoldering kind of slavery, a chain that binds you to something that will never give you what you want, and gives it power over you. They will almost certainly mistake your mercy for weakness. Do it anyway.

UNDER A BUSHEL [a repost, because i need a prod] It must be tiring. How much energy does it take, to keep all that locked up inside you? You clench your jaw shut, your lips a white line to prevent the beauty and conviction inside from spilling out. You walk slouching down the street, concealing a dazzling fire inside a coat you hold closed. Because it's in you. That lone ability, that solitary grace that shames you so because it isn't more. It burns and whirls and raves in its captivity. Containment takes strength. It takes discipline. And it takes fear. The vague, geopolitical fear of a state in the grip of a cold war, never knowing when the enemy may strike, keeping constant vigilance. The controlling, lurking dread that haunts a warden holding a terrible prisoner. It's in you, and you forbid its release. For fear of what might happen, out there, to this precious only treasure you keep. For fear of what might happen to you if it ever got free and lost. For fear of what might happen to your world when it sees the light of day, the transformations that could be wrought by its power. I imagine the control you must exercise, keeping your face still as emotions pass like great undersea leviathans, without leaving a trace. Holding still instead of striking, silence instead of expression, caution instead of passion. Trying so hard to be the still point in a life that's fully in motion. How much does it cost? How much does it take? You come home exhausted. You barely muster the energy to get through your routine. When the night comes, you collapse into bed. And while you dream, daybreaks of brilliance peep out from under the blankets.

I LOVE TO FEEL THE RAIN IN THE SUMMERTIME Who imagines the lives of clouds? Starting as a saltwater haze over a limpid tropical sea, trembling, climbing into the great shimmering vault of sky. What is it like to gain reality from the relief of a cool breeze? Trailing white limbs like gossamer, drifting, remaining formless but gaining substance all the while. Cruising the wide sky highways, gathering numbers, intersecting, tumbling, interpenetrating and reforming and parting and combining, an orgy of fluff, all the while approaching the great hurdle of a continent. Then to reach it and break like a wave, thrust up, overpiling, jammed up against the ceiling of space, a great anvil shape trailing ice against the rim of the earth. From below, they appear as an inverted sea, steepening, undulating, deepening, darkening. From above, they are a riot of billows and tufts ripped from a Parrish fantasy, playing with whatever the sun gives them - pearl gold or blinding true white, or, at dusk, scarlet or soft violet or salmon or peach or some twilight color so ephemeral it lacks a name. Finally, in the night, coming to an end, weighed down with flight and long journeys, a spectacle of days and nights sailing the sky. Emptying themselves in a storm of tears that lack sorrow or joy. The death of clouds is the life of the earth, and the leaves and puddles all whisper the gossip of far-off seas, swirling winds, scorching sunsets. The earth is grateful. In the night are those who turn their faces up to feel the clouds kiss their cheeks and eyelids. Others sleep, deep untroubled dreams of love. When the clouds weep, it is because they long to live again. Puddles. Trickles. Streams. Rivers. The sea. Currents. Heat. Torpor. A shimmering haze rises in the afternoon.

IF YOU SEE THE WONDER OF A FAIRY TALE [you can take the future even if you fail] Stevenson crosses the few blocks from Our Lady to the cafe with the box tucked under his arm, making his way in those few hours between late morning and mid-afternoon when he still has the energy he can remember always having. Those hours are like a gift to him now. The rest of the time he finds he grows tired so easily. Aside from the box, he wouldn't attract attention. But it's a garish orange with a blast of blue graphics on the lid, the logo for a shoe company whose name consistently eludes him, a box that once held sneakers for someone he can only assume was a giant. The box he keeps with him, always. He has a suitcase, too. But it doesn't come with him. Changes of clothes, a shaving kit, are necessities, a kind of social politeness. Kindly people let him place it for the day here and there ~ the cafe, the post office, behind the doorman's desk at Rue Martine, occasionally with the wizened Father at Our Lady. It rests among their feet like a snoozing cat until he comes back for it. The box is different. The box is what Stevenson has left. He had more, much more. A whole house full of things and a garage besides. But the family drained from the house, then the love, then the trappings, then the furniture, and then, finally, Stevenson. It's simple, really, what's tucked under his arm. A scarf. Three books. A painting his child stuck to the fridge. Photos he took travelling. Of his wife. A thumb drive filled with files he hasn't opened in a decade, so obsolete that to port it he needs an adapter that no one ever seems to have. A jade sea turtle, no bigger than his fingernail. A journal he kept in college when his mind was burning. And tucked into the pages of that journal, two letters he can't bear to read or to throw away. A white gold pendant with two pearls, but no chain. It seems as big, as full as everything else around him. A balance, tiny substance versus meaningless profusion. It seems natural, this slow sloughing off of things, the winnowing away. Others have more use for the rest of it. He forgets himself sometimes, thinking of the contents of the box. But here he is, crossing the street, glancing up at the poplars lining it, their crowns turning gold while their lower branches blithely continue pretending its summer. What brought him here, back to France and this little city in Provence? Closure? A longing to complete a cycle? Memories? Nostalgia? They might as well be one, he thinks. Here he is, and it doesn't look like he's going much further. ***** Aurelie finishes tidying up the attic room, gathering up the bed linen, putting the simple array of cookware and flatware back neatly on the shelf above the stove. Collecting the few possessions of Mme Sagnier and putting them in a box, the same box Sagnier brought in with her when she came. It's the same stuff she's used to finding ~ a few trinkets, writings, pictures. She takes care to find them all. She has nearly a dozen collections like this now. They clutter one wall of her own apartment, but she can't seem to part with them. Sometimes she'll find herself musing over them, trying to imagine their meaning. The enamelled hummingbird brooch. The battered map of Turkey. Aurelie wonders which face she knew in this photograph? Was it the parent or the child? It's no surprise to her that they're drawn here. They hear about it in the cafe downstairs, perhaps even visit one of the residents during their short tenure. It has a queer reputation; Aurelie has mixed feelings about it, pride mixed with melancholy. And it's a lovely room, almost quaintly cramped, but streaming with light ~ a little balcony over the street, another window opposite, and the huge skylight, forty eight panes as big as her hand, and after all this time, it heroically refuses to leak. It turns the sky into an aquarium. Most of the furnishings were her mother's, and she supposes that's comforting, too, right down to the blocky microwave and the telephone that's attached to a wire coming out of the wall. Installing the little WC on the landing at the top of the stairs was worth all the effort. Now, if only I could get a month's rent from it, she thinks, rising, hefting the slight weight of Mme Sagnier's things. She's on the ground floor landing when Jacob pokes his head in from the door that adjoins the cafe. He says, "Monsieur Stevenson thinks he might like to see the upstairs room." Aurelie nods, opening the door to her apartment. Jacob lingers, expectantly. She says, "He's here now?" Jacob steps aside to reveal Stevenson standing almost shyly to the side of the counter. And immediately her eyes fall on the box. Of course they do. How couldn't they? She sets Mme Sagnier's things on a chair just inside, and closes her door. "Come on through, Monsieur Stevenson," she says in her best English, even though his French is quite good. "It's on the third floor. A bit of a climb, but I think you'll agree it's worth it."

And perhaps it is the historian in me, determined to make a story of it, that sees the rifts & divides & failings that existed in us from the beginning, leading us to where we are now. That the overwhelming energy that made us so brilliant, is eventually what flung us apart. Is it a weakness to grieve that disintegration, to fight the heat death of spreading so far & so thin? Because fighting it is what I seem to be doing. Strangely enough, it seems to be working. The ones I care most about seem to draw closer to me, even as they slip through my fingers. There is so much love for me ~ love like low-hanging fruit, love like a red carpet, love like a jacuzzi. I never expected it, however much I may have loved. I can't tell you how fortunate I feel. I was raised to see love as a weakness. It never did anything for anyone, except make you a sucker. Dependent, helpless. I was lied to. And now, I find myself amazed, saying This has power? I can make things happen with this? Can I remake the world, the way I want it to be, just by planting these tiny seeds? I was likewise raised to believe power was a hard-boiled thing ~ dominance, force, coercion. The gentleness of the power I'm experiencing, of the power that, to my astonishment, I am wielding, is so gentle ~ like an artist painting light into a darkened scene. You must pardon your humble narrator. I speak of love so often. Only because it's such a mystery, still revealing itself to my wondering, almost disbelieving, eyes. I speak of the politics of love, because each would have you believe the other did not exist. A friend told me tonight that they were going to start blogging again, so that I could keep up with them better, as a kind of tribute to how much they thought of me. You might also enjoy US Weekly, and get to intimately know some celebrities. I'll stick with it here. There are some people here I don't know any other way than through this site ~ and I'm grateful for them, and it. This is more than a place for people to update where they're going to be tomorrow night/tonight/last night, or what their latest achievement on Farmville might be. People express themselves here ~ what troubles them, where they're going, and what compels them to go there. If you're lucky, you can find strangers and actually become friends, without ever meeting them. That's been a unique experience for me. And I need to keep up my end. So let me just say for now that recently, I have been struck by my ordinariness. There is no shame in this feeling, no guilt. Just recognition. Ordinary. Most of us are, but we build these narratives around our ambitions and thoughts and struggles that make us feel like we're in the center of a drama, that something heroic might occur from our actions. Another casualty of age I suppose, as what you hope to do becomes gradually what you've done. I'm just a guy, with a job, and a girlfriend, who lives simply. I live in the mightiest nation on earth, but it & I have almost nothing to do with one another, incidental contact. We are not so much at cross purposes, as living in different worlds. I have ambitions and dreams for myself like most ordinary people do, and those around me smile and nod when I mention them as you would if you were humoring a mental patient. I've had some thoughts. I am reluctant to share them. They are big, somewhat complex, and not entirely pleasant. I will probably lay them down here eventually, just to get them out and make room for something else. Diana proved yet again how much she deserves to be my best friend, and I love her for it. Rachel and I have been snuggling our way through winter. THOUGHT THERE'D COME A DAY I'D RUN OUT OF THINGS TO SAY [but now i know it's true, no one listens anyway-hay, yeah!] "What makes you write?" I got asked, and for a full minute I was unable to articulate an answer. It turns out, he was actually trying to ask me would you rather be rich or famous? and I should've expected as much; he's very rewards-oriented. But your humble narrator is much more internal, and a pretty obsessive bastard, and thus has been turning this question over for a full day. So, for the none of you who asked, here's what I came up with. Despite the fact that it has turned out to be the longest-running failure of my life, I continue to write because it helps me figure out my life, however obliquely. The main trouble I have with life is that I love things way more than they love me, probably more than they can love me, because I am an idealistic, sentimental idiot that entertains all manner of cockamamie notions about how love could transform life into something without so many limits. But there are just enough people out there to whom this attitude looks like an endless gravy train suckerfest, that I've had to learn to temper my feelings, and try to adapt. I don't think I'm alone in this. For the most part, that's why my characters suffer. That's why they lose so often. An inability to adapt, to temper, to cope. Perhaps my lack of happy endings will be my undoing, rendering me unfit for public presentation. Well, so be it, I guess. I don't have anything else that compels me to write about it. That's where my truth is. Maybe I'll end up like Henry Darger, privately crooning over his Vivian Girls, casting frolics & battles over yards of butcher paper. Writing's the only thing I think I do particularly well, and it is the only thing I've set myself to that I've wanted to excel in. I'm no tortured artist. I'm not even an artist. I'm more like a mason than a sculptor. What I do may not make you sigh, but you can live in it. I tell stories. And I try to make those stories honest, even when everything in them are completely egregious and unapologetic lies. Ever since I can remember, I've struggled to make myself clearer, to make what you read off my page more lucid, to say what I mean. But with this most recent piece, I came to realize that all of that kind of missed the point. Two of the characters spend most of the time avoiding saying what they mean, lives of obfuscation, subterfuge, fishing for what others think by flirting with the truth, escaping responsibility by never committing or rejecting or admitting a thing. It wasn't hard to find models for these people. The third character is straightforward and earnest. He loses. You may appreciate someone who speaks plain & clear. You might like, or even respect them. But what I've learned is that people who speak amorphously, who only hint at a great show without ever really pulling up the curtain... they fascinate you. You love them, the mystery of them. You almost can't help yourself. & so I clack away, hoping that, instead of trying to teach you anything new, I might help you remember something important that maybe you've forgotten. I love words, the endless invention of them, that they can make dialogues, ideas, rules, sex, puzzles, worlds, impossibilities. I try to get better, closer to home, more like life, more subtle, more precise. But this post is way longer than I intended it to be, so maybe I'm not even very good at that.
